message: In Hawaii, one of the most diverse states in our country, we hold the belief that no person should be discriminated against based on their religion, origin, race, ethnicity, or nationality. That value is central to our strength, resilience, and prosperity. I was proud to join Sen. Cory Booker today in introducing legislation that would block the establishment of a federal religious registry. http://www.schatz.senate.gov/press-releases/schatz-booker-warren-markey-murray-sanders-leahy-merkley-hirono-introduce-legislation-to-block-establishment-of-federal-religious-registry
I’m deeply honored to serve in this new leadership role. We have a lot of work to do in the Senate, and this new post puts me in a better position to help shape and defend our priorities.

We have a choice in front of us:  Do we build on the progress of the Affordable Care Act or do we strip millions of Americans of their health care coverage, leave those with preexisting conditions out in the cold, and raise the national debt?  We all know the Affordable Care Act has its flaws.  No one ever said it was perfect.  But its benefits are undeniable.  And that’s what we should be debating—improvements to the ACA, not an implosion.  Let’s keep our eye on the ball and remember what our common goal is – giving every American the opportunity to get the quality, affordable health care they deserve.

Hawai‘i has a deep, storied relationship with active duty service members, military retirees, and veterans, and as the lead Democrat on this subcommittee, I look forward to continuing the bipartisan tradition the Appropriations Committee has created to honor those that have served.   I am committed to ensuring we make the appropriate investments in military construction, training ranges, resiliency, and the sustainment of mission-essential buildings necessary to ensure the military’s readiness while deployed, and that we have the resources to take care of them when they return. More than 120,000 veterans call Hawai‘i home, and in my new role, I will work to ensure the VA has the funding it needs to fulfill our eternal obligation to continue to improve and expand access to quality and timely care to all veterans and their families, including those suffering from the physical and psychological wounds of war.
My message to Senate Republicans: Don't vote for a climate denier.  #RejectPruitt

While a president should be able to pick his or her cabinet, there ought to be exceptions. This week alone, we saw three – Scott Pruitt, Betsy DeVos, and Tom Price. I joined Chris Hayes on MSNBC to discuss why I’ll be voting no on all three.

The Keystone XL and Dakota Access pipelines are simply not in our national interest. While countries like China and Germany continue to make progress in their transition away from the dirty energy of the past, this action will roll back the progress we have made. Encouraging the production of this oil, which includes Canadian tar sands – one of the dirtiest fuels in the world -- is a huge step backward. Climate change is the challenge of our generation, and we need to be moving forward with policies to support clean energy.

Our next attorney general will face critical challenges that will test our justice system and our values. The Department of Justice needs a leader who can fully commit to protecting democracy and civil rights for all Americans, and build on our country’s foundation as a nation of immigrants. Senator Sessions is not that leader.   Read more about my decision to oppose Senator Sessions’ nomination here: http://www.schatz.senate.gov/press-releases/schatz-to-oppose-sessions-nomination-for-attorney-general
NA

The secretary of state is our nation’s top diplomat. He or she is responsible for advancing our national interests and keeping true to our core values. That means this person must have the knowledge base and skill set to represent American principles and pursue peace through diplomacy. After reviewing his record and his testimony before the Senate, I do not believe Mr. Tillerson is the right person to lead the State Department.  From international human rights to the grave threats facing our country, Mr. Tillerson’s views do not align with well-established, bipartisan foreign policy. The United States has built our global leadership on a foundation of core American values of liberty and justice for all—values that were missing from Mr. Tillerson’s testimony in his nomination hearing. The concerns I had regarding the South China Sea and Russia also deepened as we went through the confirmation process.  Some of those concerns bleed into questions about Mr. Tillerson’s knowledge of U.S. diplomacy and his ability to translate his skills from ExxonMobil to the State Department. Before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Mr. Tillerson outlined his vision – one that would support short-term military operations rather than long-term global engagement.  It is a view that is inconsistent with the mission of the State Department and, in fact, overlaps with the Department of Defense.  The next secretary of state will need to argue for our values and our priorities with friends and adversaries alike. This leader will also have a historic number of vacant senior career professional positions that risk being filled with people who don’t know how to run the State Department and our embassies overseas. At a time when our country is facing a historic variety of challenges in almost every part of the world, there is no safety net to catch an inexperienced diplomat. That is a risk we cannot afford to take. I will vote no on his nomination to lead the State Department.

This Muslim ban is disgusting. It's un-American. It is contrary to everything we stand for.   We are tied together by our love for America. This is who we are.   Read my full speech here: https://medium.com/@SenBrianSchatz/now-is-the-time-to-reaffirm-americas-promise-stand-against-the-ban-dd527737b40e#.b5lfm9v8i

This ban is un-American, and it is contrary to everything we stand for. It's time for every member of the U.S. Senate to speak up, stand against it, and fight chaos and paranoia as official government policy.

Supreme Court nominees should be held to the highest standards, because the Court has the final word on rights that are fundamental to the lives of Americans: our right to privacy, reproductive rights, the right to vote, and equal justice under the law.  I am disappointed the President has nominated someone who does not appear committed to ensuring these rights and who is outside of the legal mainstream. Judge Gorsuch was picked from a list provided to President Trump when he was a candidate. This list was curated by the Heritage Foundation, an organization dedicated to advancing a radical agenda of the diminishment of individual and civil rights.  Judge Gorsuch has consistently ruled in favor of corporations over individuals, has undermined women’s rights, and has failed to protect workers from discrimination. I will continue to study his record, and I will pay close attention to his hearing. But this was a missed opportunity to select a mainstream judge who could have garnered bipartisan support.

I'll be voting NO on Rex Tillerson for Secretary of State. Here's why:

When President Gerald Ford repealed the executive order interning Japanese Americans, he asked citizens across the country to make a pledge.  He said, "I call upon the American people to affirm with me this American Promise—that we have learned from the tragedy of that long-ago experience forever to treasure liberty and justice for each individual American, and resolve that this kind of action shall never again be repeated."   That promise is being broken. It’s broken for the American who came to this country as a Lost Boy from Sudan, and who now cannot see his family.  It’s broken for the American married to an Iranian who the government is splitting from her husband. It’s broken for the millions of Americans who want us to always have the moral high ground.   The world is watching.  History is watching. And we have to ask ourselves—what do they see? Do they see Lady Liberty? Or do they see something darker?  The choice is ours. We can fix this.
NA

Last night, Senate Republicans spent hours worrying about whether Senator Elizabeth Warren hurt Jeff Sessions’ feelings. In the meantime, Muslim families are terrified. In the meantime, DACA kids are wondering if they have to go into hiding. In the meantime, LGBT youth are bullied in school. And in the meantime, anti-Semitic attacks are on the rise across the country.  The Senate is a place of privilege. Its dome was built by slaves. It’s a place where there were hardly any women, people of color, gay people out of the closet, until very recently, and we spent hours worrying if it’s impolite to quote the full statement of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.’s widow.  What a luxury it is to worry about that.
Senator Sessions says “good people don’t smoke marijuana.” Tell that to the cancer victim. Tell that to my good friend John Radcliffe, who has stage 4 liver and colon cancer. I'm voting no.
Senator Sessions says voter fraud is the problem. Voter fraud is not the problem – voter disenfranchisement is the problem. I'm voting no.

Senator Sessions’ troubling record should concern everyone who cares about fair pay, reproductive rights, access to health care, and access to services for survivors of domestic violence. I'm voting no.
How much will the Muslim ban and border wall cost? I wrote to the U.S. Government Accountability Office (GAO) to find out.
To my Republican colleagues: If you are not a climate denier, don't put one in charge of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. #RejectPruitt

Scott Pruitt is the wrong person to the lead the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. The health of our planet and our people is too important to leave in the hands of someone who does not believe in scientific facts or the basic mission of the EPA.  I’m speaking out on the Senate floor to oppose his nomination.

Yesterday, an Oklahoma Judge ruled that Scott Pruitt needs to release his emails from his time as Oklahoma's attorney general by Tuesday. Today's vote needs to be delayed. Scott Pruitt is the wrong person to lead the EPA, and the American people need to know what is in those emails. We need to #RejectPruitt

I am asking that we delay this vote until every member of the Senate can read and review Scott Pruitt’s emails. There are members of the United States Senate on the Republican side who have been on the right side of climate but all that gets washed away because you don’t get to be on the right side of climate and vote for a climate denier #RejectPruitt

We are working with local law enforcement and the FBI to do whatever we can to keep Temple Emanu-El safe. Anti-Semitism is on the rise across the country, and we all must come together as a community.
Rising Antisemitism Calls for Action, Leadership from All of Us.

These new reports make it clear: Attorney General Jeff Sessions cannot and should not be the person to investigate the Trump campaign’s ties to Russia which now include the Attorney General himself. The reports also make clear that this administration struggles with telling the truth. We need an independent prosecutor, and we must empower all relevant committees in the Congress to conduct an exhaustive, bipartisan, and transparent investigation.

The Department of Justice has a unique position in our constitutional democracy that relies on trust and respect for the law. Given the challenges that the Department faces with its investigation into Russia’s ties to the campaign and to this administration, it is essential that we have an Attorney General who has the full faith and confidence of the American people. Jeff Sessions has lost that trust, is operating under a cloud, and can no longer faithfully discharge his duties as Attorney General.  Therefore, I ask that Attorney General Jeff Sessions give serious consideration to stepping down in order to restore the public's trust in the Department of Justice.

This administration continues to use immigrants and refugees – those fleeing from violence –  as scapegoats for global terrorism.  This ‘updated’ Muslim ban is still a Muslim ban. It may be more carefully constructed, but it is still racist and counterproductive. It's a violation of American values that only damages our national security.

Last night, Republicans revealed their plan to scrap the Affordable Care Act and replace it with something that is much worse: TrumpCare.  This bill is a complicated, rushed mess that will cut Medicaid and will move up Medicare insolvency. It will increase taxes for the elderly while cutting taxes for the rich. It will blow up the debt and deficit and we have no idea how many people will lose coverage.   We have the opportunity to work together to continue to improve health care. But TrumpCare is not the way to do it. We need to find a better way.

It wasn’t so long ago that gender determined whether or not you could get an athletic scholarship for college, or if a sports league would hold a championship game.  But that all changed thanks to Patsy Mink, a U.S. Representative from Hawaii who drafted Title IX, a single sentence that made gender discrimination in education illegal.   The impact Title IX has had on our country cannot be overstated. While we haven’t reached full gender equality in this country, we are much closer today thanks to Patsy Mink. #InternationalWomensDay

In 2011, Carissa Moore made history when she became the first woman to compete in the men’s Triple Crown of Surfing. The world champion has been making waves in the surfing world since she was 11 years old, inspiring girls (and boys) to pick up a surfboard.   "Girls can do exactly what the guys are doing," Moore has said. "We can do airs, we can do huge power carves, but with a little grace too."  Following in the wake of surfers like Rell Sunn, Moore reminds the world that gender should not define potential—not in the water, and not anywhere else. #InternationalWomensDay

The Women’s March made history earlier this year. And it all started with a woman from Hawaii named Teresa Shook.   The night after the election, the retired attorney created a Facebook event calling on women to march on Washington. It famously went viral—and brought people from 60 countries on seven continents out into the streets. It was the single largest gathering of people to march for a cause in history.   I was proud to be a part of the March, just as I was proud that it all started with one woman who decided she would not stand by in silence. #InternationalWomensDay

If there was ever any doubt that Scott Pruitt is a climate denier, this settles it. Anyone who denies over a century’s worth of established science and basic facts is unqualified to be the administrator of the EPA. Now more than ever, the Senate needs to stand up to Scott Pruitt and his dangerous views. We will do this through the appropriations process, through oversight of his agency, and by making sure that the Clean Air and Clean Water Acts are followed. His views are extreme, but he cannot change the law by virtue of his irresponsible views. He is still obligated to follow the law.

There’s no doubt that there’s plenty of room for improving health care. But CBO makes it clear: At least 24 million people will lose health care coverage under #TrumpCare.  We can’t impose this catastrophe on the American people.

Today, the Senate will vote on an online privacy bill — and if the Republicans get their way, internet service providers will be able to collect your browsing data and sell it.  When you think about how much of your life is online today — banking, health, even information about your kids — it’s incredibly personal. It’s not just confidential information — it’s a complete picture of everything you are. And that’s why it’s worth fighting over. It’s worth protecting.

Now that Trumpcare has crashed and burned, Republicans are going to try to do the same thing—tax cuts for the rich—but this time, instead of funding it by cutting Medicaid, they’re going to charge people more for groceries.   Here’s their proposal: to cut taxes for corporations—again— but this time, have American families pay for it through taxes on groceries and other goods we all rely on. We’ve seen this before—it’s a giveaway for corporations and wealthy people. But, as usual, we have to find a way to pay for it. So they’re going to keep proposing so-called solutions for health care, infrastructure, or in this case, they’re calling it tax reform. But make no mistake: they’re all the same proposal. It’s a subsidy for Wall Street.  Last week, we saved health care for 24 million Americans because people across the country stood up to fight. This week, the fight goes on—and once again, far too many people are in the cross-hairs. I believe that, so long as we continue to stand together, we can win this one too. A huge tax cut for the wealthy cannot be funded by increasing the cost of groceries.
NA

President Trump's latest executive order reverses the historic progress we've made on climate for short-term gains that will go straight into the pockets of oil, gas, and coal companies. This is another attempt by this administration to weaken environmental protections and America's leadership and economic dominance in clean energy.  Now is not the time to turn our back on the growing clean energy economy, and that's exactly what this executive order will do.
I'm voting NO on Neil Gorsuch and will oppose any effort to advance his nomination.

Scott Pruitt is changing the way the EPA makes policy – he’s leaving out two key sources of input: scientists and the American people. Ignoring science and the people that are directly impacted by the air and water the EPA is tasked with protecting is the wrong way to make policy. That’s why I’m demanding answers.
If Senate Republicans can't get the 60 votes to confirm Neil Gorsuch, they should change the nominee, not the rules.

Today will go down in history as the day Republicans deepened the divides in the Senate, the Supreme Court, and the country. Instead of changing the nominee to reach bipartisan consensus, Republicans chose to change the rules. In doing so, they weakened one of the last bastions of bipartisanship at a time when polarization is at an all-time high. I’m deeply disappointed and concerned by the Republicans’ actions, which were pushed through in a brazen effort to further politicize the Supreme Court.  The Senate rules exist to encourage bipartisanship, deliberation, and compromise. Now that Republicans have successfully put one of those rules on the chopping block, we will have more difficulty achieving those purposes.

The Assad regime’s use of chemical weapons is abhorrent, but a military response is not the answer.  The president has failed to articulate a strategy to end the Syrian civil war.  A one-off strike may satisfy our desire to hold Assad accountable, but it risks deeper escalation without any sense of direction or objective.  And unless this conflict ends, we will never defeat ISIL and prevent its return.  Regardless, Congress must debate and authorize any escalation of U.S. military involvement against the Syria regime, as it is well beyond the 2001 Authorization for Use of Military Force.  The United States must focus on leading a diplomatic effort among our partners and allies in the region to achieve a political solution that results in a post-Assad Syrian government that brings stability to the region.
Mahalo to all who came to my town hall meeting in Hilo yesterday.

Hawaii faces unique vulnerabilities from tsunami, hurricanes, and coastal flooding. My bill, which was just signed into law, will strengthen our ability to forecast all of these so that we can be better prepared for the threats we might face. At a basic level, this means safety--but as important, it means that businesses can plan better so fewer jobs are lost, and people will be able to maintain their livelihoods. The better forecasts this law supports will benefit everyone, and shows how it is still possible for the Congress to come together to stand up for American communities.
Jeff Sessions doesn't get it. Hawaii is home to Pearl Harbor, the birthplace of President Obama, and where Senator Dan Inouye represented us for decades. We are proud to be the 50th state.

In Hawaii, we are proud of who we are and what we contribute to the country. I spoke with Wolf Blitzer today about Jeff Sessions’ insulting comments about our state and U.S. District Judge Derrick Watson. Take a moment to watch if you can.

This week marked the first 100 days of Donald Trump’s presidency and it was unlike anything anyone has ever seen before. From the nominations of unqualified cabinet secretaries like Betsy DeVos and Scott Pruitt, to the failed attempt at banning Muslim refugees from our country, this administration and this Congress have governed with cruelty and have broken every promise they made to the American people.

Despite the proposed cuts and threats of a government shutdown from the administration, Congress was able to come together and agree on a spending bill that reflects our priorities as a country. It will protect federal funding for Hawai‘i and increase federal spending for the Coast Guard and programs that support medical research, clean energy, and science. From Native Hawaiian programs to our military, this appropriations bill funds all our key priority areas. Our entire local economy depends on these resources so this will be a relief for many residents.

When FCC Chairman Ajit Pai announced his plan to end net neutrality last week, he said “this is a fight that we intend to wage, and it is a fight that we are going to win.”   He's right. This is going to be a fight, and we're ready. Are you? Join us.

This week, congressional appropriators released a bipartisan spending bill, and Hawaii did very well. People in Hawaii can feel comfortable that through the 2017 fiscal year, we've got stability in federal resources across all executive agencies.

House Republicans just rammed through a bill that would strip at least 24 million Americans of their health care and raise the costs for those with pre-existing conditions. It’s shameful and immoral. But it can stop here. The Senate has the opportunity to walk away from Trumpcare and instead work in a bipartisan way to improve people’s health care, not take it away.
Let today be the day for Republican courage — because it wasn't yesterday, and we can't wait until tomorrow.

A couple of weeks ago, I had the honor of delivering the commencement address at my alma mater, Pomona College. The advice I gave those graduates is advice I’d give to almost anyone: There is no one older, wiser, or smarter than you trying to solve the big challenges we face. It’s up to you. It’s up to us. Do what you can with what you have.

We need accountability and transparency in these investigations. We need to get to the bottom of this for the American people. I joined Wolf Blitzer on CNN's The Situation Room today to discuss why.

We are appalled and disappointed, but we are not deterred. Entering a formal withdrawal would take nearly four years to complete which means climate change is on the ballot for every election until we reverse this immoral action.  The future is with clean energy. The future is with innovation. The future is with climate action. We are not going to allow this short-sighted decision to damage our prospects as a country and as a planet. With private sector momentum behind clean energy, states, cities, and regions are taking action. With international cooperation, we will win this fight, without President Trump’s participation.

Former FBI Director James Comey’s prepared testimony confirms recent reporting from the New York Times and the Washington Post and casts even more suspicion on the White House. I joined Chris Hayes on MSNBC to discuss why we need to get to the bottom of this.

Honouliuli National Monument is set to receive more than $150,000 in federal funding. These funds will help tell the stories of the Japanese Americans who faced discrimination during a dark chapter in U.S. History.

The Ninth Circuit’s decision to uphold Judge Watson’s ruling against President Trump’s Muslim ban is another win for the rule of law. The courts continue to affirm what we already know: the Muslim ban is un-American, unconstitutional, and contrary to everything we stand for.
It’s a very simple question: What exactly is Attorney General Jeff Sessions recused from? I tried to get the answer today from Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein.
I asked Trump’s health department secretary if secret Trumpcare meetings with 13 men would benefit from having a woman involved.  He wasn’t sure.

Thanks to all for what you do. It is energizing to know that lots of people in Hawaii are more engaged than ever before. Enjoy the holiday weekend.
Republicans are on a mission to do away with net neutrality. Today is the day for action: speak up and be heard.

Our effort to secure more than $266 million in funding for Hawaii is well on its way. I know how critical this funding is to Hawaii, to the success of our military, and to our national security, which is why I’m glad to see this bill clear this hurdle. I’m also pleased that this bill takes care of our veterans in Hawaii. Our nation has made a promise to veterans, and this bill will help us keep it. We can build for the future while also honoring those who made it possible.

The University of Hawai‘i Sea Level Center (UHSLC) will be receiving more than $1 million in federal funding to support climate and sea level research. With this funding, UHSLC will better be able to help forecast high water events no matter what the cause. Whether from hurricanes, king tides, tsunami, or some other force of nature, the Center monitors water levels all over the world, which, in these times, is more important than ever.

The Senate Republicans are about to take one of the most reckless actions in this body’s history. They are going to vote to repeal the health care system we have, without revealing what system they are going to replace it with.

The Republican so-called "skinny repeal" bill would leave 16 million Americans uninsured, raise premiums by 20%, and blow up the individual insurance market. It's time to start over, have some hearings, and work through a bipartisan process.

Today, Republicans will attempt to move ahead with a bill that would strip millions of their health care coverage and light the insurance market on fire. But we can stop them. The fight for health care isn’t over. Do whatever you can today. Stand up. Speak out. Resist.

We stand for the people. It’s that simple.

Language is fundamental to the identity of Native Hawaiians. This new funding will support the Manoa Heritage Center’s mission of preserving the Hawaiian language and all aspects of Native Hawaiian culture.
Mahalo to all who came to share their views with me on Molokai today.

I recognize that Donald Trump is the legitimately elected President of the United States, but part of the job is to provide moral leadership, to condemn hate and violence, and to simply know the difference between Nazis and the people who protest against Nazis. I joined Wolf Blitzer on CNN to discuss why President Trump has failed to meet that moral test.

My Medicaid for All plan would create a public option and give every American the opportunity to purchase health care coverage through Medicaid, an efficient, state-run program that has worked well for decades. Learn more about my plan here:
I sat down with Wendy Osher of Maui Now to talk about the concerns I heard from Maui residents at my town hall and give an update on my work to secure federal funds for Maui and the entire state.
Together, we protected the progress we’ve made on health care. Now it’s time to start making the current system work better for everyone, and my Medicaid for All bill is one way to do that.

“The conversation is shifting,” said Senator Brian Schatz, Democrat of Hawaii. “Because even if you don’t believe liberals, even if you don’t believe scientists, you can believe your own eyes.”  "Mr. Schatz, one of the Democrats’ most assertive spokesmen on global warming, said there were already “pockets of opportunity” to work with Republicans on measures to reinforce coastlines and support solar- and wind-energy production, though not on more ambitious policies."

Both were prompted by news of the Equifax hack announced last week, which compromised the personal information of as many as 143 million Americans.

The latest version of Trumpcare is worse than the last. Democrats will do what we can, but what will kill this bill is public pressure.

Republicans are again attempting to repeal the Affordable Care Act, and this new version is much more radical than the last one. I joined Chris Hayes on MSNBC tonight to talk about what we need to do stop this latest effort.

"Sen. Brian Schatz (D-Hawaii), along with Sens. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.), Cory Booker (D-N.J.), and Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) are demanding to know why the Trump administration plans to make the website inaccessible for 12 hours on nearly every Sunday and on the first night of the 2018 open enrollment period."

The Equifax breach is one of the many recent reminders that cyberattacks are not going away. These kinds of attacks on businesses—big and small—leave Americans exposed. That’s why I wrote the MAIN STREET Cybersecurity Act. My bill, which just passed the Senate, will give small businesses the tools they need to beef up their cybersecurity and prepare to fight back.

The Trump Administration has failed in its response to the Puerto Rico emergency. They were too late in mobilizing the military. They did not coordinate a full government response. And they did not treat this with the urgency that it deserves.   It's a quite unusual leader from either party who fails to recognize you ought to do everything you can for people and, at a minimum, not get into petty squabbles.

A year ago we learned Wells Fargo was harming customers by creating millions of fake bank accounts and collecting fees from unsuspecting victims. After a year of investigations, we have only learned about more consumer abuses. And the bank still made a whopping $5.8 billion in profits in the last quarter alone. It’s unbelievable. That’s why at today’s Senate Banking Committee hearing, I demanded answers from Wells Fargo’s CEO and called for the bank’s charter to be revoked. We need real accountability.

We have real challenges with North Korea that require a well thought out plan combining sanctions, military readiness, and diplomacy.   That’s why, last week, during a Senate Banking Committee hearing, I asked U.S. diplomats to think carefully about our strategy moving forward.   President Trump’s decision to make threats in 140 characters cannot be ignored by our government. We need to take a realistic approach to this escalating crisis—one that acknowledges the role this president plays, whether our diplomats and military leaders like it or not.
Equifax left millions of Americans exposed. They alone should pay to fix it. I sat down with Senator Van Hollen to talk about the Equifax scandal and what we can do to hold Equifax more accountable.

This week, our hearts are with the people affected by this recent tragedy, and with all of Las Vegas. But warm words are not enough. Thoughts and prayers won’t stop this from happening again. There are a number of steps we can take to keep people safe.  We can start by making sure dangerous guns don’t end up in the wrong hands. And we can do this by applying comprehensive and rigorous background checks and closing loopholes that allow terrorists to buy weapons and let others get around registration rules by buying guns online. People who fail a background check or who are too dangerous to get on an airplane should be too dangerous to own a gun.   We can also try to prevent mass shootings by limiting the kinds of guns that are sold. The shooter in Las Vegas took less than 15 minutes to kill 58 people and injure more than 500. It’s unbelievable. By banning dangerous high-powered assault firearms and high-capacity ammunition and holding gun manufacturers more accountable, we can make sure weapons that are more suited for a war zone aren’t sold in our communities.   And finally, we need to find more ways to identify and stop potential killers. This means addressing the connections between gun violence and issues like mental health or domestic violence.  It’s time for Congress to finally stand up against gun violence and take action so that what happened in Las Vegas never happens again.

Republicans haven’t given up on decimating our health care system. They are still trying to cut Medicare and Medicaid—and they’re going to try to use tax reform to do it. Their proposal will cut $473 billion from Medicare and $1 trillion from Medicaid and increase the federal deficit by roughly $4 trillion. That’s not conservative. It won’t help working families. And it’s not going to help us grow the economy.

Once again, the administration has put partisan ideology above the health of the American people, our economy, and our planet. Like their failed attempts to undermine clean water and methane rules, this effort to repeal the Clean Power Plan has no basis in law and will absolutely be challenged in court.  Climate change is the challenge of our generation. It’s our obligation as the indispensable nation to lead and take action. The administration’s short-sighted decision today abdicates that role. But in the absence of leadership from the White House, momentum behind clean energy is growing, as states, cities, and the private sector continue to move ahead. Our commitment to fighting climate change won’t be weakened. We will continue to take action, with or without the administration’s help.

The president’s threat against NBC and other media outlets is far from empty. In 1974, President Nixon and his top aides discussed using the FCC’s license renewal process to punish the Washington Post for its Watergate coverage. Today, Donald Trump has threatened to do the same to NBC. In confirmation hearings for Ajit Pai, we raised this possibility. Now, the FCC must show that it is loyal to the law, not the president, and make clear that it rejects this kind of interference.

Today, President Trump nominated Barry Myers, the CEO of AccuWeather, to lead the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.   Mr. Myers is a questionable choice. He views NOAA as a direct competitor that provides high-quality forecasts for free. He is in the vanguard of special interests that seek to undermine the National Weather Service’s ability to do anything other than provide free data and weather models to private companies like his, which then turn around and sell their forecasts.   Mr. Myers will have to work very hard to persuade me that he will run NOAA for the public good—instead of trying to run it out of the business of saving lives and property and protecting our national security with its weather forecasts.  Since Mr. Myers and his two brothers own and operate AccuWeather, he will also need to explain why his service as NOAA Administrator will not violate conflict of interest rules and regulations.   Additionally Mr. Myers will need to persuade me that he has the expertise to manage the nation's leading ocean agency, which oversees commercial and recreational fisheries, coastal land stewardship, and the conservation of endangered marine species, when he does not have any formal scientific education or training.   I will keep an open mind throughout our Senate review of his nomination, but I am disappointed that this administration would nominate someone with Mr. Myers' controversial views on the National Weather Service, especially given the potential for conflicts of interest involving his family and his scant qualifications to run the rest of the agency.

When credit reporting agencies like Equifax make mistakes that leave millions of Americans exposed to the risk of identity theft, they alone should pay to fix it. There is no reason these companies should be profiting off their own errors by charging consumers for credit report freezes. At a Senate Banking Committee hearing today, I tried to get some answers from a representative of the trade association for Equifax and other credit reporting agencies.

Pride is a time to celebrate. And part of what we’re celebrating is the progress that has been made for gay, lesbian, bisexual, and transgender people in Hawaii and across the country. That progress took decades of work from countless Americans. Activists had to organize. Lawyers had to fight. People had to find the courage to come out to their friends, their family, and their co-workers, and ask them to stand up for LGBT rights.   This year feels a little different. Because in 2017, the Trump administration has rolled back the clock and erased some of the gains we’ve made on protecting LGBT Americans from discrimination in schools, at work, and in our military.  We’ve taken a few steps back this year, and we’re going to have to fight even harder in pursuit of equality. But if we’ve learned anything from the history of LGBT Americans, it’s that we can make a change. As much as today is a moment to celebrate, let’s also make it a day that we commit to getting involved.
Jeff Flake will be missed.

With nearly 30 million people still without health insurance, it’s time to close the gap and pursue universal coverage. Today, 18 senators and Congressman Ben Ray Luján joined me in introducing the State Public Option Act, a bill that would unlock each state’s Medicaid program to give Americans a public health insurance option.  Building on the Affordable Care Act, my bill would allow people to go on their states’ exchanges and sign up for a Medicaid plan.

“The challenge of the next half century is whether we have the wisdom to use that wealth to enrich and elevate our national life, and to advance the quality of our American civilization.”  Those are the words of President Lyndon B. Johnson when he unveiled his plans for the program that would become Medicaid. More than 50 years later, we are still searching for that wisdom. When the next round of health care policy comes, Democrats must be ready to get it right.

"The State Public Option Act, sponsored by Sen. Brian Schatz (D-Hawaii) in the Senate and Rep. Ben Ray Luján (D-N.M.) in the House, would expand Medicaid from a program available only to Americans at or slightly above the poverty level, to a universal program anyone could buy into. Already, 18 Democrats in the Senate have co-sponsored the bill."  "Schatz had worked on the bill for months, inspired — as he told Vox in August — by the surge of public support for the Affordable Care Act’s Medicaid expansion that followed Republican attempts to repeal “Obamacare.”

"I think we have to do several things at once. I think we have to have an affirmative economic agenda. I, of course, feel passionately about the climate. But, you know, when you talk to individual voters and families, a lot of these issues merge in their lives. It’s the cost of electricity, it’s the cost of insurance, it’s wage stagnation. Politicians think of these issues in silos. But my judgement is, most people just think that the cost of living is too high. And that’s an economic issue, a family issue, and you can even call it a healthcare issue. But the bottom line is: Their own personal arithmetic just doesn’t add up. And that’s what Democrats should be focused on – helping people make their own personal math work, so that they can at least break even. Or, maybe, get ahead."

This week Congress awarded Filipino World War II veterans with one of our nation’s highest honors— the Congressional Gold Medal. These brave Filipino veterans answered the call of duty and fought under our flag with great courage and valor. One of those veterans I met was Salome Calderon. She told me about her story serving as a spy in the Philippines. During the war, she scouted bombing targets and delivered critical intelligence for our military. Then there was Lucio Sanico. He served as private first-class in the 1st Filipino Infantry Regiment, a unit of the U.S. Army made up of Filipino Americans. He recounted his service in Leyte and Samar engaging in mop-up operations as a 21 year-old. Salome, Lucio and more than 250,000 others have been waiting more than 75 years for this recognition, and this week, thanks to the leadership of Senator Mazie K. Hirono, they finally got it.

As the former Administrator of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, Andy Slavitt knows firsthand how Medicaid helps millions of Americans stay healthy. That’s why he supports our legislation that would unlock each state’s Medicaid program to anyone who wants it.

Every public official needs to know the facts about climate change: it’s real, it’s caused by human activity, and we need to do something about it.   So I asked the president’s nominee for Assistant Secretary of Transportation for Research and Technology about her views on extreme weather. Her answer was not exactly satisfying. Watch:

If you ask someone nominated to lead America’s space agency if they agree with the scientific consensus on climate change, you would expect the answer to be yes.    Congressman Jim Bridenstine does not meet expectations. Not even close.

Every American should have access to affordable, quality health insurance. But, even with the progress we’ve made with the Affordable Care Act, nearly 30 million people still don’t have health insurance. In Hawaii alone, more than 70,000 people are without coverage.   The goal of my new State Public Option Act is to close this gap. In Hawaii, this would mean opening up Med-Quest to every resident, regardless of income. It’s time to unlock Medicaid and make sure that every American has health care at a price they can afford.

I just landed in Bonn, Germany, for the United Nations Climate Change Conference. We’re here to tell the world that no matter what the president says, we’re still in the Paris Agreement. We’ve come too far for U.S. momentum on climate change to stop now.
We’re in Germany for climate talks to show that the United States is still committed to climate action.
The message we are conveying at the climate talks in Germany is simple: the President is powerful but he cannot stop the clean energy revolution.

Climate change is the challenge of our generation. It’s our obligation as the indispensable nation to lead and take action. While the president may not be showing leadership on this, I have joined with some of my Senate colleagues at the COP23 UN Climate Change Chance Conference in Bonn, Germany, to show the world that #WeAreStillIn on the Paris Agreement. Veterans Day is an opportunity for all of us to take the time to honor the men and women who have served in our military—to say thank you, and then learn more of the stories behind their service. There are more than one hundred thousand veterans living in Hawaii, and millions across the country. So please join me in thanking these great men and women. And then take some time to discover the quiet, courageous ways they’ve shaped our nation’s history.

Vice President Al Gore continues to be one of the strongest leaders in the fight to solve climate change. He is a leading voice on clean energy, and I was honored to join him at #COP23 to discuss the way forward on this critical issue.
Last update from the UN Climate Change Conference in Germany.
Whatever the president’s rhetoric, he can’t prevent us from moving forward on clean energy.
A quick update on the Republican tax plan

I wanted to share this with my FB folks to see what you think. As the son of a Principal Investigator I’m somewhat cautious about scientific declarations made without sufficient research, but the fact that in states where medical marijuana is available the opioid death rate was 25 percent less is hard to ignore. But the most interesting thing about the hearing questions (bear with me it’s a bit long) is that the VA docs were more than open to this, and didn’t disagree at all. I’m going to get with staff and talk through next steps but this is encouraging.

Since its formation, we’ve seen a free and open internet grow our economy and our imaginations. But today the FCC has threatened to end the internet as we know it. If adopted, the FCC’s plan will change the way every American gets information, watches movies, listens to music, conducts business, and talks to their families. By repealing basic net neutrality protections, the FCC is handing over full control of the internet to providers, leaving the American people with fewer choices and less access.

This bill hasn’t passed yet. There’s still time to kill it. It will be awful for the middle class, and especially bad for Hawaii. Thanks for all of your participation in the democratic process.

76 years ago today, Lt. William Outerbridge spotted a Japanese submarine lurking in the waters surrounding Pearl Harbor. The sub was one of five sent by the Japanese that infamous day.    Outerbridge decided that his destroyer, the USS Ward, would take action, and instructed his crew to fire the first shots in World War II’s Pacific theatre. Within hours, the attack on Pearl Harbor was underway.     On Pearl Harbor Remembrance Day, we honor the courage of service members who took decisive action. We remember the 2,403 Americans who were killed that day. And we take inspiration from the resilience of Pearl Harbor and the men and women who did what they could with what they had to keep our Navy fit to fight.

This week the FCC will vote to roll back basic net neutrality protections, ending the free and open internet as we know it. This move will take away your ability to use the internet the way you want to and instead give it to internet service providers. It’s time to make net neutrality a voting issue – and a movement.

"This fight right now is about whether the Department of Defense and the Department of Defense only gets more resources, and what we’re saying is if you stand by servicemembers, you have to stand by veterans,” Schatz said. “That means funding defense and non-defense on an equal basis.”

Over the past decades, the internet has done miracles for economic growth and American innovation. Tomorrow, the FCC will vote to repeal net neutrality protections that have kept the internet free and open, making it harder for entrepreneurs and small businesses to use the internet to grow. This is a bad move for consumer choice, and it’s a bad move for our economy.

Today, Trump’s FCC dealt a major blow to the free and open internet by repealing net neutrality rules. Because of Chairman Pai and the other Republican commissioners, there are no longer any rules in place to stop internet service providers from changing the internet as we know it. They are now free to block apps, slow websites, or even limit access to certain kinds of content. The best way to move forward is to turn our tweets and our comments into action.
The FCC’s decision today to roll back net neutrality means that service providers can charge different amounts for different content. It’s wrong.

The tax code is an expression of what America cares about and what America values. In this bill we are telling people that we value work less than we value already being rich. There’s nothing with somebody who has been successful but to the extent that passive income now is taxed at a lower rate than people who actually earn their money the old fashioned way by working it, that’s a reflection of values and I think that’s why people are so concerned about us entering into a new gilded age.
